DEGREE OF A DIFFERENTIAL EQUATION The degree of a differential equation is the degree of the highest order derivative, when differential confidentsare madefreefrom radicals andfractions. In otherwords, the degree of a differential equationis the power of the highest order derivative occurring in adifferential equationwhen itiswritten asapolynomial in differential coefficients. n2 ILLUSTRATION 2 Consider the differential equation -4y =0. dx^ In this equation the power of highest order derivative is 1. So, it is a differential equation of order 3 and degree 2.

The integrating factor o for ^ +Py =Q is e Pdx o B dx d e Pdx Multiplying both sides of (i) by€● , wre get a u Pdx dy Podx d Pdx Pdx ee -ff + Py = QeY=> -r^y^' = Qe' R d n i F . w o l F e e r r F u r o o f s Y k o o B d e r a u o e Y dx dx R On integratingboth sides wdith respect to x, we obtain I n Pdx Pdx y^ F iQe dx +C ...(ii) This is the required solution, where Cis the constant of integration. The solution (ii) in short may also be written as y(I.F.) = Q(I.F.)dA: +C Following algorithm may be used to solve a linear differential equation. Such type of problems are said to have unbounded solutions. Consider the followinglinear programming problem. Maximize Z = 2x+ 3y Subject to the constraints x + y>2 x + 2y>3 x,y>0 The common feasible solution set of this LPP is the set of all points in the shaded region of Fig. 29.28.
